item.title: Make It Explicit
item.description: Recently I did some pair programming and code review with a developer, we added deep links into our Android application. All in all that's a pretty simple task. During the cycles of code review and pairing I realized that I first recommended to use one technique during pair programming, just to argue against it in a later on in code review. That made me think - Do I have some type of split brain thing going on here?

item.title: Master Your Tools
item.description: Today I found “Most tech content is bullshit” by Aleksandra Sikora. Good title, right? üòÅ In a nutshell her post says: all information on the internet is written by people who don't really know. And I'd say she's right about that. Still we point to them and say “this is the authoritative source, we should follow it!". I have seen & heard the same hand-wavy arguments, from junior, senior, tech leads, engineering managers, architects - really any job title and level of seniority.

item.title: Work @ Rakuten Tech in Covid Times
item.description: I haven't worked from the office since 20th of February, that's a little over 2 months. The one time I stopped by at the end of March to pickup a testing device and a big monitor I met about 4 people out of ca. 70 in my department. The office is a ghost town, with tumbleweeds and all. We've all adjusted our lives significantly, we learned to cope as organization and as individuals.

item.title: Curated Media Vol 3
item.description: The best of timeless media since Volume 2. Everything is worth a read, listen or watch - good writng & good content. Enjoy! Open House (n+1) Jeremiah Moss’ visceral description of gentrification in the East Village. How it feels when they come and take over. Utterly unblemished, physically fit, exceptionally well dresssed, as bland as skim milk and unsalted saltine crackers. Insta-apartments. First come the cleaneres, sending up the chlorine tang of bleach, followed by the movers with their tidy plastic totes, followed (at least once) by professional furnishers.

item.title: Code Camp CV Advice
item.description: CV fresh out of freeCodeCamp I saw this career advice question on freeCodeCamp: I‚Äôve been applying for jobs and I am getting really frustrated since I am rejected each time I apply. Perhaps there is something wrong with my resume Last year I read hundreds of CVs and conducted close to a hundred technical interviews while hiring developers for my company. My key takeaway is: Hiring is tough - on both the candidate and the interviewer.

item.title: Emotions at Work: Ownership
item.description: Some weeks are shit. I mean really shit. Come into work Monday, starting with a mindless morning meeting, all the way through a day chopped up by more meaningless meetings, annoyning emails and a constant stream of instant messanging interruptions. At the end of such a day I feel like I got nothing done, nothing worth working for at least. And it's rinse and repeat from there, the whole week. üòµ

item.title: Notifications and Meetings
item.description: So I shut them down. No more banners, no more app badges, no more sounds, no more jumping dock yelling at me about IM, email, calendar, … well no app interrupts me anymore - unless I chose to. The payoff after one day: it felt more productive than usual. I wrote properly worded emails, a report, reviewed 3 pull requests worth of code, drafted a proposal on how to improve our documentation and helped out some engineers by arranging a training for them.
